original_data.question: A 55-year-old man presents into the emergency department with a severe cough and difficulty breathing. He says that he finds himself out of breath after taking a few steps, and has to sit down and rest, in order to continue. He also says that, at night, he has the greatest difficulty in breathing and usually uses at least 3 pillows to sleep comfortably. He mentions a cough that appears only at night, but which is persistent enough to wake him up from sleep. He mentions that he has had a ‘heart attack’ 5 years ago. He also says that he continues to consume alcohol on a regular basis even though his doctor has advised against it. He has brought his lab reports which he had recently got done on the suggestions of his family doctor. An electrocardiogram (ECG) and a chest X-ray are found. Which of the following is the next step in this patient’s management?

model_response:
The ECG shows atrial fibrillation with a ventricular rate of 100/min. The chest X-ray shows a normal cardiac silhouette and clear lung fields. The patient’s symptoms, history of alcohol consumption, and the ECG findings are suggestive of atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response. The patient’s symptoms are due to the rapid ventricular rate. The first step in the management of this patient is to control the ventricular rate. This can be achieved by using medications such as beta blockers, digoxin, or calcium channel blockers. An echocardiogram is not indicated in this patient as his symptoms are due to rapid ventricular rate and not due to a structural heart disease. A stress test is not indicated in this patient as his symptoms are due to rapid ventricular rate and not due to exertional dyspnea. A cardiac biopsy is not indicated in this patient as his symptoms are due to rapid ventricular rate and not due to a structural heart disease. A CT scan is not indicated in this patient as his symptoms are due to rapid ventricular rate and not due to respiratory symptoms.

Answer: OPTION A IS CORRECT.</s><s>

A sudden, audible expulsion of air from the lungs through a partially closed glottis, preceded by inhalation. It is a protective response that serves to clear the trachea, bronchi, and/or lungs of irritants and secretions, or to prevent aspiration of foreign materials into the lungs.

A clear, colorless liquid rapidly absorbed from the gastrointestinal tract and distributed throughout the body. It has bactericidal activity and is used often as a topical disinfectant. It is widely used as a solvent and preservative in pharmaceutical preparations as well as serving as the primary ingredient in ALCOHOLIC BEVERAGES.
